My roommate and I came here around 9 PM on a Saturday night (they close at 10 on sat) and about 1/3rd of the restaurant was full. It's a little hidden gem off of 24th that I've had bookmarked for a while and I'm so glad we finally went. 
 The ambiance is very San Juan and colorful, the whole place is really cute. I'm vegetarian, and everything on the menu sounded amazing to me. Puerto Rican restaurants hardly offer vegetarian dishes, and this place had tons of options. I ordered the mofongo vegetariano, plaintanos meduros, and a side of white rice and black beans. My roommate had the buttermilk chicken and ate ever last bite. All of the portions are decent sized and the plates are put together beautifully. 
The food was amazing. 10000 times better than any other Puerto Rican restaurants in the Bay Area (except for a certain sol food in San Rafael). The service was meh, but the food trumped all. We ate every last bite. 
After we paid, the chef came out to our table to introduce himself and ask how we liked the food. He said to ask for anything vegetarian next time and he'll do it (;

The staff is very friendly and attentive which makes for a four star establishment!

camarones al ajillo.author: Tim D.
camarones al ajillo.review:
I had wanted to try this restaurant for some time but was always hesitant due to the inconsistent reviews it's received on here.  My Puerto Rican partner's craving for home cooking and his desire to give this caucasian American a taste of the Island finally won out and I decided to give it a try with an open mind, and I sure am glad I did!  

We arrived Sat. around 1:00 PM and only two of the 12 tables were occupied, with one waitress on duty.  After an hour about half of the tables were filled, all with what appeared to be local Mission folks, including a charming elderly couple, which I took as a good sign of authentic food.  On this day, service seemed casual as opposed to slow (as other reviewers have reported), but I could see it perhaps slowing down if it was too full or if too many people arrived at once.

Food-wise, everything we ordered was delicious, including the each-piece-separately-toasted French table bread.  I ordered the Pastel app. on Yelp's recommendation, which I enjoyed quite a bit but wished was more tamale-like for my personal taste.  The Al Capurria was like a yummy meat-filled yucca donut which I'd definitely order again.  The complimentary chicken soup was as good as I'd want a chicken soup to be, properly salted and with very soft, moist chunks o'chicken.

For entrees we had Ropa Vieja (which my parter swore was properly cooked and had an authentic flavor), and Camarones al Ajillo, seven perfectly cooked shrimp in an amazing lemon-butter sauce.  We also tried the Chiles Rellenos just for the sake of comparison, and although they were much wetter than I expected or have had before (served in a casserole dish filled with sauce), they tasted great.  The breading was of course not crispy due to all the sauce, but it was still discernible and added to the flavor and texture of the peppers.  

Regarding the side of beans which others have reviewed as "watery and bland," my partner says the thinner sauce is the authentic Puerto Rican style.  I don't personally like watery beans, but I found this sauce to be just thick enough on its own and was especially good with the addition of rice, which I mixed in to all the sauces we were served. I felt the beans were "delicately spiced" rather than bland, meant to be a basic accompaniment, not a main flavor feature.

Some reviews on here have negatively critiqued the decor, though I found it to be basic but charming, likening it to a restaurant you'd find along the road while traveling in the Island countryside.  It at least appeared to be very clean.  I didn't give the restrooms a try.

I don't know if time of day or day of week are factors in some of the inconsistencies people have reported, but I'd recommend making your own decision.  Just be open-minded in regards to some of the negative comments and you should be OK.

I am willing to give this place a 2nd chance, if someone on yelp can recommend a few of the outstanding dishes to try out.
camarones al ajillo.author: Lauren S.
camarones al ajillo.review:
I had such high hopes for this place. Since it's the only Puerto Rican restaurant in SF (that anyone can find) I really wanted to give it as much praise as I possibly could.  

Unfortunately, I'd have to rate the food at Fruitilandia as so-so at best.  I  started with the Mofongo, which had a delicious garlic sauce but I couldnt taste any of the bits of pork, and the large pieces of fried tostones nearly chipped my teeth.  My sis had the Yuca Con Mojo (yucca with garlic).  She really loved that dish and I thought it had a great flavor but the yucca is way to rich for me.  My little nephew had the french fries, which were the best fries I've ever had anywhere, yummy!  Next, I tried the fried pork chops with rice and black beans.  Again, flavor was fabulous but the chops were fried to a crisp.  Sis had the Camarones Al Ajillo, Shrimp with Garlic.  The only problem with this dish was that it should've been described as shrimp with wine sauce because the wine was soooo overpowering, that was all we could taste.  The mango juice was refreshing and the chicken soup was good.  I am willing to give this place a 2nd chance, if someone on yelp can recommend a few of the outstanding dishes to try out.

pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-nuevo-frutilandia-san-francisco?select=7z7dSx5OhmVq7libj_0C_w#-jA4oaVrkuxWf5FcYfflsA
Very juicy, tender pork. For this cut of meat, it's still a little on the dry side. Compared to my pork chops, this was much more moist. It's drenched in sauce, but biting through a thick chunk of meat, you do get to the dryer (though still soft) meat in the middle. Just me being picky. Rice & black beans were good.


ENTREES (pt. 2), SANGRIA: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-nuevo-frutilandia-san-francisco?select=7z7dSx5OhmVq7libj_0C_w#N3MQSz_pOTi4bB1_t4mniQ
* Chuletas de Cerdo Fritas (pork chops spiced w/ garlic & mango sauce, topped w/ sauteed onions $14) - 3 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-nuevo-frutilandia-san-francisco?select=7z7dSx5OhmVq7libj_0C_w#6hlk7Zo3gw5cQfxC1n3ibg
I was intrigued by the mango sauce, but couldn't taste this at all in the end. This ended up being a very basic pork chop dish, nothing too special. Came with rice & black beans.

* Guava Sangria (white wine, guava $6.50) - 3.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-nuevo-frutilandia-san-francisco?select=7z7dSx5OhmVq7libj_0C_w#hBXdP8R1BC4DPL6I4LnHjA
Light flavor-wise, like a tropical sangria. My boyfriend got a glass of this and moved to the Mango Sangria, which basically tasted like a red sangria.

Mango Sangria

SWEET TREATS: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-nuevo-frutilandia-san-francisco?select=7z7dSx5OhmVq7libj_0C_w#nY5oZV87SJF1MUdHPKlSog
* Tres Leches Cake (sponge cake soaked in evaporated milk, condensed milk & heavy cream, topped w/ cream cheese frosting $7) - 4.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-nuevo-frutilandia-san-francisco?select=7z7dSx5OhmVq7libj_0C_w#bpTQFcVHPgRVu6w1u1pOsQ
Wow, that was a *thick* layer of cream cheese frosting on top! I love my sweets but that was a little too intense. However, on the cake--I've been on the hunt for an amazing tres leches in SF and I think I've found my holy grail. This was intensely soft, moist, and heaven in our mouths.

excerpts: The standard most be low on 24th Street because I ordered the  Bistec De Palomilla (Tender thin top sirloin steak sauteed with orange-lemon sauce garnished with onions and parsley.
includes rice, black beans, and soup )and I can't even say it looked good.
It was Not tender and a bit flavorless.
Like a rubbery chip steak.
bistec de palomilla.author: John W.
bistec de palomilla.review:
A little disappointed actually.  After hearing some hype on the joint and remembering I got a quite delicious Cubano sandwich from them at the San Francisco Street Festival, I was excited to try the place especially after being turned away a week ago because its was packed, close to closing time, and claimed "they were out of food".
Tonight there it was only about 20% full, perhaps because its a holiday weekend.
The standard most be low on 24th Street because I ordered the  Bistec De Palomilla (Tender thin top sirloin steak sauteed with orange-lemon sauce garnished with onions and parsley. includes rice, black beans, and soup )and I can't even say it looked good.  It was Not tender and a bit flavorless.  Like a rubbery chip steak.
My partner had the Ropa Vieja (Shredded flank steak cooked in creole sauce, onions, tomatoes, wine, and bell peppers. includes rice, black beans, and soup).  It wasn't even actually what he ordered but it was comparable as far as the menu was concerned so he just went along with it.  I tasted it and though I liked it better then my order, it was certainly nothing to write home about.  Presentation was that of a school cafeteria and there wasn't even a plantano on the plate.  Portions were small.
I may go by there again for the Cuban Sandwich during lunch hours someday if I'm in the hood but don't hold your breath.  
We will stick to our favorite in the Haight for this style food from now on.  It has price points, atmosphere, and presentation.  None of which I could vouch for this place.  Go to Parada 22 instead.

excerpts: Now I can't say how they do PR food or sandwiches, but I can tell you they don't do Bistec de Palomilla well at all.
And that's enough for me to know not to comeback.
Why?
Bistec de Palomilla is the quintessential Cuban dish.
bistec de palomilla.author: Gil M.
bistec de palomilla.review:
1 star seemed too harsh, so I'm going with 2. But the fact that I considered going with 1 star should tell you something.

I'm 1st generation Cuban American, originally from Miami, FL, so I know my way around the Cuban Food block. Now I can't say how they do PR food or sandwiches, but I can tell you they don't do Bistec de Palomilla well at all. And that's enough for me to know not to comeback. Why? Bistec de Palomilla is the quintessential Cuban dish. White rice, black beans, and steak. Done. A Cuban joint messing that dish up is like an Italian restaurant doing lousy spaghetti and meatballs. 

The palomilla at Frutilandia was greasy, the seasoning was all wrong, and it was pounded way too thin. If that wasn't bad enough, the white rice had some rock-hard, bottom of the dish grains in it. As for the black beans, they were passable. 

The entree came with a salad which consisted of lettuce 2 slices of tomato and Veg-all corn, carrots and green beans. It was kind of a travesty, actually. The best part of the meal was the warm bread and the nice server. Everything else was bad and low budget.

Good service and atmosphere go a long way with me and I don't know about their PR food or sandwiches, so I'll give them the benefit of the doubt and give them 2 instead of 1 star.

excerpts: i long for Bistec de Palomilla done the right way.
bistec de palomilla.author: Gina L.
bistec de palomilla.review:
I would give it 3 stars if there were more Cuban or PR restaurants in the city to which I could compare this one to, but there aren't.  So 4 stars it is.  Because honestly, I enjoy dining here.

They have this great chicken dish thats covered in some sort of green sauce.  A little on the salty side, but pretty tasty otherwise.  Standard rice and beans.

Do NOT, and i repeat, DO NOT, respond with "salad" when asked for "salad or soup"... it is the most bare salad i've ever been served, and they don't even offer dressing.  At most, some olive oil and pepper.  The soup, on the otherhand, is delicious and absolutely bread-dip worthy.


The city needs more Cuban restaurants... i long for Bistec de Palomilla done the right way.

excerpts: Will 100% be coming back to try the Vaca Frita and a few of the other items on the menu.
Stop by if you are in the area and make a trip there if you're not!
vaca frita.author: Valeria S.
vaca frita.review:
I was on the hunt for some good Puerto Rican food in SF and was excited to try this place out. I've had plenty of mofongo in my life and this is definitely one of the better ones! The sauce was so tasty and good and full of flavor with some nice garlic and sazón. The mofongo itself was excellent, not dry at all and the pork that came with it was very well flavored. 

I also ordered the habichuelas (red beans) and arroz con gandules as my sides and this was enough for two people. Both of these sides were really tasty but the arroz con gandules was definitely the highlight. 

Picking the dessert at the end was a very hard choice but I ended up going with the tres leches and was very happy. It was a big portion and really nice and sweet and just everything you'd want from tres leches. Put waiter was super nice and patient, especially since we were being indecisive about a lot of our order. 

Will 100% be coming back to try the Vaca Frita and a few of the other items on the menu. Stop by if you are in the area and make a trip there if you're not!

excerpts: Got the vaca frita, a crispy shredded beef dish with onions wth the Puerto Rican rice.
The beef was crispy and flavorful and the rice was the perfect balance to the meat.
For appetizers got the yucca frites, tostones con mojo, and alcapurras.
All were solid and good.
The food here is great and authentic and you can't  beat the price and portions.
One of my favorite places in all of San Francisco.
vaca frita.author: Peter P.
vaca frita.review: An authentic taste of Puerto Rico in the mission. The food is amazing. The prices are more then reasonable dare I say cheap for SF given the generous portions. It's a small cozy welcoming place. Chill vibe with music and a very friendly staff. Despite my dislike of a sunglass wearing bleached blond food network star loving this place, the food speaks for itself. Got the vaca frita, a crispy shredded beef dish with onions wth the Puerto Rican rice. The beef was crispy and flavorful and the rice was the perfect balance to the meat. For appetizers got the yucca frites, tostones con mojo, and alcapurras. All were solid and good. The food here is great and authentic and you can't  beat the price and portions. One of my favorite places in all of San Francisco.

excerpts: Then I had the vaca frita (shredded flank steak) with rice and black beans and it was amazing.
This is my favorite dish my mom makes, and this was up there with hers (actually even a more flavorful).
I also had the passion fruit mango juice and it was super tasty.
In short, I can't recommend this place enough!
vaca frita.author: Ana M.
vaca frita.review: My mom's Cuban and my dad's Puerto Rican and I actually grew up in Puerto Rico and I can honestly say this place is the bomb. Super authentic and delicious in every way. I went last night in need of some home cooking in the wake of Hurricane Maria and this spot delivered. I had some of the alcapurrias (fritters) stuffed with picadillo (ground beef) and they were bomb. Then I had the vaca frita (shredded flank steak) with rice and black beans and it was amazing. This is my favorite dish my mom makes, and this was up there with hers (actually even a more flavorful). I also had the passion fruit mango juice and it was super tasty. In short, I can't recommend this place enough!

excerpts:
The Vaca Frita was as good as anything I had eaten in Miami, and they even offered Mamey milk shake!
The restaurant is jointly Cuban and Puerto Rican, so some dishes are a happy mix of both, Puerto Rican rice with Cuban beef, etc.
vaca frita.author: Lars A.
vaca frita.review:
A while back I spent three months in Miami and got to really appreciate the local cuisine, especially the Cuban restaurants.
Back home in SF I had not been able to have the same experience until I found this place.
The Vaca Frita was as good as anything I had eaten in Miami, and they even offered Mamey milk shake!
The restaurant is jointly Cuban and Puerto Rican, so some dishes are a happy mix of both, Puerto Rican rice with Cuban beef, etc.
I did not try the Mofongo (next time), but the Tres Leches cake was easily among the best I have had anywhere.
Compared to the Cuban corner places in Miami, the food here is a little more - for lack of better words - cleaned up, lighter, and the portions are more "reasonable".
Staff is very friendly and helpful, restaurant is comfortable, small enough to be cozy, just a little prone to noise maybe.

excerpts: I got the vaca frita as recommended by the waitress and I loved it.
vaca frita.author: Elizabeth C.
vaca frita.review: This is the best food ever!!! A lil pricy but totally worth it. I got the vaca frita as recommended by the waitress and I loved it. The taro chips are super tasty. Wish I had bought a side of them.

excerpts: That Vaca frita tho .
Be on point ever time.
My lady loves the ropa vaja or whatever.
We even ordered a catering sizes once to bring to a party.
Great date place and great with a small group.
And them appetizers won't let you down
so eat the hell up.
vaca frita.author: Alterrique I.
vaca frita.review: Bruh the food so it don't make no damn sense. That Vaca frita tho . Be on point ever time. My lady loves the ropa vaja or whatever. We even ordered a catering sizes once to bring to a party. Great date place and great with a small group. And them appetizers won't let you down so eat the hell up.

excerpts: Vaca Frita vs. Ropa Vieja?
Hands down, Vaca Frita, said she.
vaca frita.author: Helen S.
vaca frita.review:
Found this place on Yelp purely by chance and decided to come because it was open and we wanted somewhere in the Mission that wasn't crowded and serving Mexican food.

If Wendy is looking after you tonight, you're gonna have a good time. She's friendly, funny, and attentive, a winning combination in a waitress! Skills possibly honed through her past gig as a bartender. ;) Anyways, if you're having trouble deciding, you should trust her judgment. Vaca Frita vs. Ropa Vieja? Hands down, Vaca Frita, said she. And we couldn't get enough of the crispy, citrusy pieces of steak or savory taro root chips. 

Wendy's recommendations turned out to be more winning than my fellow Yelpers. I got the much touted Mofongo (with pork) out of curiosity, and while it was interesting, I wouldn't order it again. It was a mush of plantains and pork in garlicky sauce that wasn't evenly seasoned. A dish that struggled for direction and just sort of collapsed into a heap. 

The portions here are pretty small for what you pay, but there are few places to get a clean but authentic Puerto Rican experience such as the one at Frutilandia. The bright interior is sparingly but charmingly decorated in bright colors and a TV plays soundless channels. Somehow, everything just belongs together, like the coffee can turned silverware container on each table. It's a wonderful place for a peaceful meal before a busy night in the Mission!

excerpts: Vaca frita-was tender and delicious.
vaca frita.author: Will E.
vaca frita.review:
Well, this would be the first 5 that I've given out.  Heard about the place so of course I had to try it.  

Beef Empanadas-very tasty and cooked perfect. The dough was nice light brown color and flaky. Only wish more came with the order. 

Vaca frita-was tender and delicious. Cooked perfect as well. 

Lechon-so tender, flavor was awesome

Beans two different ones, both very good. Yummy. 

Mofungo-good flavor, very good. 

Tres leche-to die for. Wth. Have to try it. 

Okay enough about the food, the waitress was great with great service.

excerpts: It is one of the *very few* places in San Francisco where I can get my all-time favorite Cuban dish, vaca frita (literally "fried cow"), and it's absolutely outstanding here!
If you've never tasted vaca frita, you're missing out.
Shredded, tender garlicy-lime-marinated skirt steak that's been fried until crispy like bacon (mmmm!), served with carmelized onions, rice, and perfectly seasoned black beans.
Riquissimo! as my mom would say.
One bite
and you'll want to start a revolution.
vaca frita.author: Christina M.
vaca frita.review:
I'm a daughter of Cuban refugees who grew up in Miami and now lives in San Francisco. I wish someone had prepared me for the fact that great Cuban food would be ridiculously hard to come by in this otherwise incredibly international city. I'm talking real, solid Cuban food that tastes just like the stuff I grew up with and not a weird fusion.

And that's exactly why El Nuevo Frutilanda is such a treasure. It is one of the *very few* places in San Francisco where I can get my all-time favorite Cuban dish, vaca frita (literally "fried cow"), and it's absolutely outstanding here! 

If you've never tasted vaca frita, you're missing out. Shredded, tender garlicy-lime-marinated skirt steak that's been fried until crispy like bacon (mmmm!), served with carmelized onions, rice, and perfectly seasoned black beans. ¡Riquissimo! as my mom would say. One bite and you'll want to start a revolution. ;-)

Not only that, but Frutilandia serves something from my childhood that's even rarer -- mamey smoothies. Not familiar with mamey? Wondering what it tastes like? There's no way I could compare to anything because it's probably a flavor unlike any you've ever had. Just order it, live a little. It is one of the most delectable fruit flavors out there. Frutilandia's version of it is slightly watered down compared to the way my mom made it, but it is so refreshing on a warm day anyway. You won't find this kind of smoothie at any project juice or any Mexican restaurant. In fact, this might be the only place in town that serves them.

I realize that going on and on about foods from my childhood might not necessarily appeal to most Yelpers out there who didn't grow up Cuban, but I really don't think it's just the nostalgia talking. Cuban food is practically designed to comfort and nourish you. El Nuevo Frutilandia captures this so well, I hope they stay in business through the ages. And if the owners are reading, I recommend that you guys market/advertise your Cuban offerings much more openly, especially now that U.S. trips to Cuba are opening up!

excerpts: You must try the vaca frita, alcapurria's, empanadas de platano maduro.
Happy eating.
vaca frita.author: Maria C.
vaca frita.review: Wonderful place to eat authentic Puerto Rican food. The staff is friendly and totally love the salsa music in the background. Charming place that you all should definitely visit in the mission. You must try the vaca frita, alcapurria's, empanadas de platano maduro. Happy eating.

excerpts: My Son had the vaca frita and that was delicious!
The rest of us had the Cuban pork.
It was tender but had no flavor of the common garlic/ cumin mojo as typically expected in chunks of pork at a Cuban restaurant.
In fact it had the flavor of what you would expect carnitas to taste at a Mexican restaurant.
We also ordered fried plantains on the side, unfortunately they where so chard/
black they where not edible.
Unfortunately they made no attempt to rectify the situation, so I merely told our nice waitress not to charge us for that
and they didn't.
It does make me sad for me to say I will not eat here again.
Good luck, hope this helps?
vaca frita.author: D F.
vaca frita.review:
My  experience at Frutilandia, was a bit of a disappointment. Being myself from Cuba, I expected the food to be as good as I have had in restaurants in Miami . We had for appetizers tostones they where typical, the fried yucca; fried as if you where eating french fries with a mojo that was very bland. The mofongo was good for it being Puerto Rican. My Son had the vaca frita and that was delicious! The rest of us had the Cuban pork. It was tender but had no flavor of the common garlic/ cumin mojo as typically expected in chunks of pork at a Cuban restaurant. In fact it had the flavor of what you would expect carnitas to taste at a Mexican restaurant. We also ordered fried plantains on the side, unfortunately they where so chard/ black they where not edible. Unfortunately they made no attempt to rectify the situation, so I merely told our nice waitress not to charge us for that and they didn't. It does make me sad for me to say I will not eat here again.
Good luck, hope this helps?

excerpts: Finished off with a Vaca Frita with white rice and black beans that brought back some memories of Miami.
It's a small location but highly recommend it to all.
vaca frita.author: Ruben R.
vaca frita.review: For a Cuban living in Santa Cruz the trip to the city for this was way worth it.  Had some tostones and yuca frita. Both were great. Finished off with a Vaca Frita with white rice and black beans that brought back some memories of Miami. It's a small location but highly recommend it to all.

excerpts: Vaca Frita is amazing!
Order it!
Do it!
I am also loving my guava shake.
vaca frita.author: Christopher C.
vaca frita.review:
I am eating here right this moment!  Holy moly this half Puerto Rican is pleased.  Reminds me if mi abuelas cooking.  New favorite spot in the city for Caribbean fair.

Vaca Frita is amazing!  Order it!  Do it!  I am also loving my guava shake.

excerpts: Vaca Frita was really fantastic.
The sweet plaintains are very good.
Great service too.
vaca frita.author: April M.
vaca frita.review: Vaca Frita was really fantastic.  The sweet plaintains are very good. Great service too.

excerpts: I had the vaca frita and it was incredible!!!
vaca frita.author: Spencer L.
vaca frita.review:
This place is awesome!  Super tasty and the servers are really nice.  I had the vaca frita and it was incredible!!!  

Also their passion fruit is superb.

Was totally surprised with how good everything was.  From the beans to the salad to the empanadas. 

Overall amazing!!

excerpts: We ordered a lot of traditional foods, tostones, fried plantains, ropa veiha, picadillo, Vaca frita, and rice and black beans and finished with flan, which was home made by the owners wife.
It was fantastic.
I highly recommend this place if you need your Cubano craving.
Definitely will return when visiting SF again, which is frequently.
vaca frita.author: Barbara P.
vaca frita.review: Just had dinner at this place and it was great!  Being from Miami and visiting our son who lives on SF, we needed our usual Friday night fix for Cuban food.  Man, this place was great, however a limited menu, which is understandable  being so far from Miami and south.  The service was very good and the owner was very friendly.   We ordered a lot of traditional foods, tostones, fried plantains, ropa veiha, picadillo, Vaca frita, and rice and black beans and finished with flan, which was home made by the owners wife.  It was fantastic.   I highly recommend this place if you need your Cubano craving.  Definitely will return when visiting SF again, which is frequently.

excerpts:
We had  vaca frita: too dry and too  shreeded lacked mojo and   the portion was small, but the black beans were on point
Mofongo:
I could not taste the pork or chicharron at all but

the tomato sauce for it was amazing
Chicken soup:

Was nice great broth
Tostones: Were very good and right on point  but they should of being served with a dipping sauce
vaca frita.author: Manny R.
vaca frita.review:
So If i was eating this back in South Florida it would only get 3  stars but since it is in San Francisco the land of the taqueria,  I'll give it 4 for being different and offering a unique cuisine to the city.

We had  vaca frita: too dry and too  shreeded lacked mojo and   the portion was small, but the black beans were on point
Mofongo:  I could not taste the pork or chicharron at all but the tomato sauce for it was amazing
Chicken soup: Was nice great broth
Tostones: Were very good and right on point  but they should of being served with a dipping sauce
Maduros were good and fried correctly

Overall  it was okay but much room for improvement.

On another note the server was very attentive and seem to know her menu well

excerpts: that you dip in a secret sauce), Pierna de Puerco Horneado (really tender pork with carribean spices) served with a tasty side of dish of rice and beans and my friend had the Ropa Vieja (flank steak in a creole sauce) even though I meant to tell him that I heard the Vaca Frita (fried shredded flank steak)
was the way to go.
vaca frita.author: LaSha G.
vaca frita.review:
This is probably THE only SF restaurant that specializes in Puerto Rican food from what I can tell, but don't hold me to that.  I went here with a friend on Friday night before a jazz concert at the Red Poppy Art House, and the restaurant is tiny but in a cozy way as opposed to a clausterphobic way.  The night I went there was only one lady manning the bar, taking orders, and serving food but she was really sweet and patient since I didn't know what I wanted to order and we didn't have to wait too long for anything.

Excellent dishes enjoyed that night include  Mofongo (mashed plantains and pork sauteed with garlic and olive oil...that you dip in a secret sauce), Pierna de Puerco Horneado (really tender pork with carribean spices) served with a tasty side of dish of rice and beans and my friend had the Ropa Vieja (flank steak in a creole sauce) even though I meant to tell him that I heard the Vaca Frita (fried shredded flank steak) was the way to go.  He enjoyed his dish regardless.

At $9.95 for an entre, I thought the prices here were cheap.    I'm glad I found this place (via Yelp btw) ...I'll definitely bring some friends here in the future....especially since the Red Poppy is right around the corner.

excerpts: The vaca frita I ordered instead was small and much tougher than meat that simmers for so long should be.
We waited about 45 mins.
after ordering.
The chicken soup was very bland as well.
Our waitress was very unfriendly.
My friend had some yucca that did seem pretty good.
I will not return though - worst Cuban experience yet.
vaca frita.author: Alexander G.
vaca frita.review: Really disappointing experience. Restaurant was empty apart from one table and that should be enough information right there. They were out of their special of the day (bacalao), but since it was a weekday and the restaurant was pretty much empty, I found this very hard to believe (read: they never made the special of the day). The vaca frita I ordered instead was small and much tougher than meat that simmers for so long should be. We waited about 45 mins. after ordering. The chicken soup was very bland as well. Our waitress was very unfriendly. My friend had some yucca that did seem pretty good. I will not return though - worst Cuban experience yet.

excerpts: I had the mixed appetizer platter, which was HUGE and delicious, and the Vaca Frita, which was so good it much be a sin.
Only reason I can't give 5 stars is because there was only 1 person working the WHOLE restaurant while we were there, so service was slow, and she didn't really speak English
so I ended up with red wine when I ordered white.
Otherwise, though, an excellent restaurant
and I'll definitely be returning!
vaca frita.author: Liz P.
vaca frita.review: This place has AWESOME Cuban and Puerto Rican food.  Ever since I moved out here from Florida, I've been missing good Cuban food and I finally found it!  I had the mixed appetizer platter, which was HUGE and delicious, and the Vaca Frita, which was so good it much be a sin.  Only reason I can't give 5 stars is because there was only 1 person working the WHOLE restaurant while we were there, so service was slow, and she didn't really speak English so I ended up with red wine when I ordered white.  Otherwise, though, an excellent restaurant and I'll definitely be returning!

excerpts: The Vaca Frita (although Cuban) is by far my favorite plate.
You HAVE to try it!.
Also try the Yuca al Mojo, mmm.
vaca frita.author: Noel S.
vaca frita.review: Puerto Rican here.  Great place. The Vaca Frita (although Cuban) is by far my favorite plate. You HAVE to try it!.  Also try the Yuca al Mojo, mmm.

excerpts: My friends had the vaca frita and a pork dish
The pork was a bit dry, but I also enjoyed the vaca frita.
vaca frita.author: Berna P.
vaca frita.review: I went to this place with a couple of friends for a birthday celebration, and I really enjoyed it. The Mofongo was delicious! I ordered the Bistek de Palomilla which was a bit lemony for me. It was still good, but having only tasted a few different versions, I could not say if it was more or less authentic than the other. I will definitely return to this place as I want to try the ropa vieja and other entrees. My friends had the vaca frita and a pork dish The pork was a bit dry, but I also enjoyed the vaca frita. The Mofongo though was the hit for me!

excerpts: My favorite dish is Vaca Frita and it was made exceptionally well here!
Make sure to get black beans and rice and some yuca - delicious!!
vaca frita.author: Ted D.
vaca frita.review:
Amazing!!  My mom was cuban and my dad was Puerto Rican so I was raised on delicious cuban/puerto rican food!  We recently moved to the area and I have been craving a taste of home.   We found our corner of Miami here in San Francisco!  Everything we ate was FANTASTIC!  My favorite dish is Vaca Frita and it was made exceptionally well here!  Make sure to get black beans and rice and some yuca - delicious!!  The mofongo (you are supposed to eat it with the broth!) as an appetizer was FANTASTIC!  And if you have room make sure to get a cafe con leche and some flan to end your meal just right!

It's a dive but well worth the trip and cheap!   We will be back often I am sure!  One note - they are closed on Mondays.

excerpts: it was lechon with arroz con gandules they also sell some cuban dishes they sell good ropa vieja and there vaca frita is hella good
i also had a cuban sandwhich it was on hit
i met quite a few boricuas in the bay area hopefully
one day one of them will open up a new puerto rican restaurant in san fran one day it,
s long over due but for right now
if you find your self in the city this is the only place that i know of that sells puerto rican food  on a last note the staff is very freindly....
vaca frita.author: Jose C.
vaca frita.review: i,m not gonna even say i,m an expert on puerto rican cuisine but i have been here quite a few times and the food is preatty good not the best but good i really like there tostones i also had the puerto rican pasteles and alcapurrias and they where on hit i once had a spacial it was lechon with arroz con gandules they also sell some cuban dishes they sell good ropa vieja and there vaca frita is hella good i also had a cuban sandwhich it was on hit i met quite a few boricuas in the bay area hopefully one day one of them will open up a new puerto rican restaurant in san fran one day it,s long over due but for right now if you find your self in the city this is the only place that i know of that sells puerto rican food  on a last note the staff is very freindly....

excerpts: Even though I was completely set on ordering their Lechon, there were a lot of things on the menu that sounded tempting like their Cubano Sandwich, their Tostones Con Mojo, their Garlic Shrimp (Limon Ajo Camarones), and Chile Relleno.
I definitely plan on returning again to try their Cubano Sandwich, and also all their other entrees since the whole menu sounds amazing.
cubano sandwich.author: Rodney H.
cubano sandwich.review:
I remember first trying El Nuevo Frutilandia when they were at the San Francisco Street Food Festival a few years back.  I had their Lechon and it blew my mind (bit.ly/1kKi5zG).  The pork was so tender and flavorful!  So after totally enjoying that sampling,  I was really looking forward to visiting their restaurant.  Well it took a while, but I finally made it over with a few friends.

Even though I was completely set on ordering their Lechon, there were a lot of things on the menu that sounded tempting like their Cubano Sandwich, their Tostones Con Mojo, their Garlic Shrimp (Limon Ajo Camarones), and Chile Relleno.  I still stuck with the plan and ordered the Lechon Horneado, and then decided on splitting their specialty Veggie Mofongo with my friends.  We also ordered a pitcher of their Guava Sangria.

Guava Sangria -- http://bit.ly/29VYBpT
White wine, guava
Very refreshing!  And it paired well with everything we ordered.  If you're going with a small group of people, definitely order the pitcher!!

Veggie Mofongo -- http://bit.ly/2a49ngu
Hand mashed garlic plantains topped with a tomato sofrito
This was really good!  The plantain mash was moist and had some good flavor together with the tomato sofrito  I was really surprised with the portion size because it was huge!  If you're dining here solo, unless you have a huge appetite, I wouldn't order this if you plan to order an entree after it.  This really could be a meal in itself.  Especially if you get one of the mofongos stuffed with meat.  I was definitely glad I was splitting this with my friends.

Lechon Horneado -- http://bit.ly/29IaNI4
Slow roasted pork marinated in garlic, pineapple, caribbean spices.  Ordered with Arroz Con Grandules which is Puerto Rican style rice with pigeon peas, smoked ham and bacon
Finally!!  And the first bite I had of the pork took me back to when I enjoyed it at the SF Street Food Fest.  Just like I described earlier, the Lechon is so tender and the flavor just explodes in your mouth!  They have it down to a science!  The Arroz Con Grandules is a must order with the Lechon.  It's almost like a ham and bacon paella and just completes the whole pork trinity.  And I must mention the portion size, it's a lot of food!!  Because I had the mofongo earlier, I was only able to finish half of my dish.

Overall, I say El Nuevo Frutilandia is must try in the Mission!  It's a really good spot when you're in the mood for some Cuban comfort food.  The food is delicious, huge portions, and the prices are easy on your wallet.  I definitely plan on returning again to try their Cubano Sandwich, and also all their other entrees since the whole menu sounds amazing.  It will be extremely hard to resist ordering another Lechon Horneado though.  It's so good!!!

excerpts: FYI,  the Cubano sandwich is now $18.00.
cubano sandwich.author: Bert K.
cubano sandwich.review:
What happened?

( have eaten here at least once a year for the past 8 years )

Meh.

Had the beef with red chile sauce and the pork sauteed dish; both in a similar red sauce. How strange! Each dish comes with a pinch of pickled onions and a large scoop of ok tasting rice. $15.95 and $14.95 respectively. Kinda spendy for what you get.

Had to ask for my water to be refilled. Twice in 30 minutes. There were a total of 9 people in the restaurant.

C'mon E N F ! get your game back up!

FYI,  the Cubano sandwich is now $18.00.

excerpts: My friend spoke highly of the Cubano Sandwich.
cubano sandwich.author: Emily R.
cubano sandwich.review:
Great spot! 
So they have great happy hour deals on tapas and drinks (Wed thru Fri 5pm-7pm & sun 4pm-7pm) and THE BEST SANGRIA. I don't even like white wine and they make a guava white wine sangria and a mango red wine one, which are both to die for. 

As for food, it's a fusion of Cuban and Puerto Rican food. Very good empanadas, ceviche, shrimp dishes with different marinades of rice (as well as chicken, steaks, and pork in same manner), lots of bean sides, and yucca and plantains galore! The empanadas come with a great sauce!! Good portion sizes too and fun, local vibe. My friend spoke highly of the Cubano Sandwich. 

Guy Fieri filmed here for Food Network and they are super modest about it, which is cool because I'd brag about my restaurant being on TV. 

Total great date/group place and be ready to share because food envy gets real here.

excerpts: The Cubano sandwich with extra mustard will be forever my favorite... or is it the Alcapurrias... or maybe the Ropa Vieja,
cubano sandwich.author: Chelsey B.
cubano sandwich.review:
This spot is a must to visit when you're around the Mission.
The Cubano sandwich with extra mustard will be forever my favorite... or is it the Alcapurrias... or maybe the Ropa Vieja, I JUST LOVE IT ALL!! 

When my boyfriend and I go here.. he always has to order a Sangria.
This place is awesome for a modern mom and pop type of restaurant.

excerpts: The Cubano sandwich had a slightly sweet but still kind of bland pulled pork in it.
WTF?
You can't just switch out the roasted pork and still call it a Cubano!
On top of that the bread was either stale or over cooked.
The maduro had a very strange flavor.
How can you mess up fried plantain?
On the positive side, service was nice and the habichuelas were good.
As i said, I frequented this establishment for 20+ years.
We had a great run but it's over now.
cubano sandwich.author: carol c.
cubano sandwich.review:
This reminded me of the food I had in Cuba- bland!! We have been coming to Fruitlandia on and off for 20+ years and have usually had great experiences here
I LOVE Cuban and Puerto Rican food but this place no longer does it justice at all. The ropa vieja looked like ropa vieja but tasted like salpicon (a very bland version of salpicon). The Cubano sandwich had a slightly sweet but still kind of bland pulled pork in it. WTF? You can't just switch out the roasted pork and still call it a Cubano! On top of that the bread was either stale or over cooked. The maduro had a very strange flavor. How can you mess up fried plantain? On the positive side, service was nice and the habichuelas were good. As i said, I frequented this establishment for 20+ years. We had a great run but it's over now.

excerpts: I had the cubano sandwich.
It was good but the ham on it looked liked lunch meat from the grocery store...
cubano sandwich.author: Alexys E.
cubano sandwich.review: They were at SFSFF 2013. I had the cubano sandwich. It was good but the ham on it looked liked lunch meat from the grocery store...

excerpts: Shortly after she gives us tostones that we ordered and says that they don't have any bread left for the cubano sandwich!
Why did they have to wait this long to let us know they had no bread?
We asked her to cancel our entire order since nothing had been cooked yet.
Don't waste your time coming here...
the service is not worth it...
cubano sandwich.author: H C.
cubano sandwich.review: This place is a joke! Walked in at around 745pm, the place was not entirely full. We sat down, the waitress gave us our menus over a table that had not been wiped down. Upon taking our order, the waitress informed us that there were three dishes that were not available. Upsetting, but we ordered other stuff. We waited about 25 mins and no appetizers came. I was starting to think that I should've listened to the Yelp reviews regarding the service. A party of two walked in maybe 20 minutes after we did and they got their dishes within 15 minutes! Unbelievable! I questioned the waitress and she said that our food was coming. Shortly after she gives us tostones that we ordered and says that they don't have any bread left for the cubano sandwich! Why did they have to wait this long to let us know they had no bread? We asked her to cancel our entire order since nothing had been cooked yet. Don't waste your time coming here...the service is not worth it...

excerpts:
After hearing some hype on the joint and remembering I got a quite delicious Cubano sandwich from them at the San Francisco Street Festival, I was excited to try the place especially after being turned away a week ago because its was packed, close to closing time, and claimed "they were out of food".
Tonight there it was only about 20% full, perhaps because its a holiday weekend.
cubano sandwich.author: John W.
cubano sandwich.review:
A little disappointed actually.  After hearing some hype on the joint and remembering I got a quite delicious Cubano sandwich from them at the San Francisco Street Festival, I was excited to try the place especially after being turned away a week ago because its was packed, close to closing time, and claimed "they were out of food".
Tonight there it was only about 20% full, perhaps because its a holiday weekend.
The standard most be low on 24th Street because I ordered the  Bistec De Palomilla (Tender thin top sirloin steak sauteed with orange-lemon sauce garnished with onions and parsley. includes rice, black beans, and soup )and I can't even say it looked good.  It was Not tender and a bit flavorless.  Like a rubbery chip steak.
My partner had the Ropa Vieja (Shredded flank steak cooked in creole sauce, onions, tomatoes, wine, and bell peppers. includes rice, black beans, and soup).  It wasn't even actually what he ordered but it was comparable as far as the menu was concerned so he just went along with it.  I tasted it and though I liked it better then my order, it was certainly nothing to write home about.  Presentation was that of a school cafeteria and there wasn't even a plantano on the plate.  Portions were small.
I may go by there again for the Cuban Sandwich during lunch hours someday if I'm in the hood but don't hold your breath.  
We will stick to our favorite in the Haight for this style food from now on.  It has price points, atmosphere, and presentation.  None of which I could vouch for this place.  Go to Parada 22 instead.

excerpts: We ordered quite a bit as we wwere starving: Pastel Puertorriquenos, Platanos Maduros, Alcapurria, Tostones con Mojo de Ajo, Cubano sandwich, Passion fruit shake, and sweet potato fries.
Everything tasted fine.. just not out of this world.
On the other hand, service was really good.
The place is cute, I like the location at the Mission.
Not a bad place at all.
cubano sandwich.author: Vol T.
cubano sandwich.review: I'm a fan of Puerto Rican/ Cuban food and have eaten quite a bit of it. This was just ok. We ordered quite a bit as we wwere starving: Pastel Puertorriquenos, Platanos Maduros, Alcapurria, Tostones con Mojo de Ajo, Cubano sandwich, Passion fruit shake, and sweet potato fries. Everything tasted fine.. just not out of this world. On the other hand, service was really good. The place is cute, I like the location at the Mission. Not a bad place at all.

I definitely plan on returning again to try their Cubano Sandwich, and also all their other entrees since the whole menu sounds amazing.
